body:
Good catch! This should be fixed along with #1 
I won't be able to take care of this until Tuesday or Wednesday night though. Feel free to fork the repo, commit the changes, and submit a pull request.
I think I'll keep the name as "Seen It" but change the name on the landing page as an easter egg.
I'd like to take a stab at this by making a held shift key temporarily change the skipping state. I'm pretty new to JS, so we'll see how it goes.
Awesome! This stack overflow answer might help you out: http://stackoverflow.com/a/7479406 Let me know if you have any questions
Cool, I'm pretty much there, but I'm having trouble accessing the storage, so I'm re-writing what I've got to use similar methods to your skipper.
So, I've go it working... I made a new branch called feature-keyboard, and submitted a pull request, but I don't know if that's what I was supposed to do...

I don't know if the holding shift thing should be added just yet, it would work better if enabling skip didn't force you to the next image. The intent was to be able to hold shift to go back to a post if you skipped it but changed your mind. The problem is that once you're on the post, letting go moves you to the next new post.

Nice, this is shaping up to look good. I haven't had a chance to test it yet though. Can you please set the toggling hotkeys to alt+z and alt+x (or some other key+z/key+x combo). Otherwise it could be annoying when typing a comment.
Fair point. Picking hotkeys is not my strong suit. I'll do alt.
If possible with userscript, maybe that would be better for cross compatibility? Just a thought.
Thanks to Github, it's not a surprise anymore :D
Why not make one that is just `"*://imgur.com/*"`

Oh, yeah @JuanPotato is right. Here's an example of it from the Google docs: https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/match_patterns

@kevinseguin can you change the matches field to `"*://imgur.com/*"`
Right now you can click the icon in the bar and disable skipping in the options. I think adding in #2 should count as fixing this issue.

I couldn't get it to work when I tried it. I think it's because the keyup event doesn't have two keys in one event firing. Check this out to help figure out how to check for two keys at once: http://stackoverflow.com/a/12444641
Pull request #8 made the url check for "://imgur.com" instead of needing to check for http or https. That should fix this issue.
Agreed
Ooops, there was a bug in here. `if (tab.url.indexOf('//imgur.com') === 0) {` should be `if (tab.url.indexOf('//imgur.com') !== -1) {` so it returns true when on the imgur domain.
I don't know anything about userscripts. Can someone summarize why they're more portable/beneficial?

There are ups and down.
Userscripts requires an extension to run in most browsers. (For instance greasemonkey).
When made "right" they'll for the most part work with all browsers that support userscripts (either natively or through the use of extensions)

The big benefit is that you'll have less to maintain. :)

However, native extensions are a much smoother experience for the end-user.

The event structure sends the mod keys status in keyup and key down events.
When I tried it, it wouldn't work with keypress. Can you run your debugger
and enable the keyup breakpoint? How quickly are you trying the combo?
On Sep 30, 2015 12:28 AM, "Arjun Sarode" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I couldn't get it to work when I tried it. I think it's because the keyup
> event doesn't have two keys in one event firing. Check this out to help
> figure out how to check for two keys at once:
> http://stackoverflow.com/a/12444641
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/asarode/seen-it/pull/7#issuecomment-144277922.

Oh yeah, it's working fine! Checking on key up feels pretty weird. It's nicer to be able to hold alt and then kit z or x to do enable the hot key. Are you fine with that change in behavior? Changing the event from keyup to keydown should get what we want. I'll merge when you make that change.

I converted the code to ES6 and adding in some much better organization to the code. The changes are in the feature-es6-build branch if anyone wants to check them out. I'll merge in a couple pull requests, then add the code from those pulls into the ES6 branch, and then finally merge the ES6 branch into master so we can start working with ES6!

Btw, I setup a Gitter for this repo. It's just a chatroom where people can talk about development for seen-it. Here's the link (you can also click the badge on top of the readme): https://gitter.im/asarode/seen-it

Just pulled #7 which lets you press alt+z to toggle the skip option and alt+x to toggle the storing option. We should get another issue going for enabling people to have the option to select which hotkey they want.
Just merged in #7 Thanks for the help!
Merged the code into master

You can now toggle the skipping with alt+z. There's a plan to toggle the skipping when you hold shift+left or shift+right an then toggle it again once you let go of shift. I think the shift behavior is a bit more flexible than just not skipping when you press the back key. Do you think it would still be necessary that the back button not trigger a skip if this shift functionality is added?

The shift mecanism will be fine sure !

How do you plans to detetect the shift key ?

I was thinking of waiting for the message before executing the code to parse url. But I checked and the message arrives ~200ms after, which is a lot to wait I think.
